 REPUBLIC OF KAZAKHSTAN SOCIAL PROTECTION PROJECT LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Republic of Kazakhstan Beneficiaries: Ministry of Labor Oblast governments of South Kazakhstan and Paviodar Oblasts City governments of Shymkent, Kentau, Lenger, Pavlodar, and Aksu Poverty Category: Program of Targeted Interventions. Because the unemployed includes a greater proportion of poor people than in the population at large, and the poor has less access to private social facilities, their benefit under the project would be substantially larger than their proportion in the overall population. Amount: US$ 41.1 million Terms: 17 years, including 5 years of grace, at the World Bank's standard variable interest rate. Project Objectives: The project seeks to assist the Borrower to: (a) develop the capacity of the Employment Service in the Department of Employment of the Ministry of Labor to manage the expected increase in the number of registered unemployed and attendant benefit claims following the restructuring and privatization of enterprises; and (b) ensure continued delivery of essential social services, by promoting orderly divestiture of social assets from enterprises, and efficient management by municipalities of a unified system of social services. The project would be implemented with a view to determining suitable models for the design and implementation of a comprehensive national strategy for the divestiture of enterprise social assets, thereby removing obstacles to restructuring, and enhancing the competitiveness of enterprises. The project would provide the institutional underpinning for the implementation of social policies supported by the SAL. Project Description: The project has two main components: an Employment Service Component, to be implemented at both the national and regional levels; and a Social Services Component, to be implemented in South Kazakhstan and Pavlodar oblasts. The Employment Service Component seeks to strengthen the institutional capacity of the ES to register the unemployed and calculate and pay unemployment benefits; provide a more effective service to unemployed job seekers; and analyze labor markets and formulate labor market policies. It will also develop a sharper focus for training and retraining of the unemployed, particularly women and youth, through orienting the work of the ES towards promoting demand-driven training and through a greater use of external training

Financing under this component will support: (a) institutional strengthening of the ES; (b) development and implementation of a simplified unemployment benefit (UB) system; (c) training and development of staff; and (d) a pilot program in South Kazakhstan and Pavlodar oblasts and Almaty to strengthen counselling and training of the unemployed. The Social Services Component will facilitate the transfer of essential social services from restructuring enterprises to local governments, and rationalize management of all basic social services in five selected cities -- South Kazakhstan Oblast: Shymkent City, Kentau, Lenger; and Pavlodar Oblast: Pavlodar City, and Aksu. Local social service budget management will be reformed and social assistance targeting improved. While many socially important facilities are run by the enterprises, the project will focus only on basic social services such as health care and early education, which are critical elements of the social safety net. To this end, the project will finance modest rehabilitation and upgrading of, and purchases of critical equipment and supplies for, facilities that are to be sustained over the long run, including: health (rehabilitation of hospitals and primary health care facilities and purchases of essential medical equipment, vaccines, drugs, and supplies), and (b) education (rehabilitation of kindergartens and purchases of books and training materials). Incremental recurrent costs will be financed for the divested facilities on a declining basis, with counterpart contributions from the Governmenlt Benefits: The policy making capacity of the Employment Service will be improved, and the basis laid for a program of social protection for retrenched workers. The provision of an effective social safety net would remove constraints on labor mobility and improve public support for the Government's economic strategy. Enterprise restructuring will be facilitated in the selected cities by the orderly divestiture of social services. The project will foster rationalization of local social service budget management and improve public social investment programs in the selected cities. Improvements in the cost effectiveness of local social expenditure will have a net positive impact on the central budget, reducilng the need for increased budgetary allocations resulting from divestiture, while allowing local governments to operate additional divested social services. Experience with the rationalization programs in the two oblasts would facilitate replication/improvement of the approach subsequently throughout the country. Risks: In a newly created country undergoing fundamental economic transformation, there is an inevitable risk of policy changes and implementation delays. The project faces five main risks: (i) the Government's limited experience with Bank- financed projects and overall limited administrative capacity; (ii) the complexity of the issues to be addressed; (iii) introduction of user fees for health services may be delayed because it requires changes in legislation; (iv) the Government may find it difficult to sustain the level of management, coordination, and budgetary effort necessary to succeed in the divestiture process; and (v) delays in implementing policy reformns may jeopardize project implementation. The project will help offset these risks by: putting in place strong institutional arrangements; implementing the Social Services Component in oblasts/cities

 I. INTRODUCTION A. Econonmic and Sectoral Background 1.1 At independence in 1992, Kazakhstan inherited a reasonably well-developed industrial base. Industry, dominated by mining and processing activities, accounted for about 40% of GDP and agriculture 34%. Per capita GNP was estimated at US$1,690. However, the economy was characterized by inefficiencies common throughout the FSU, including distorted price structures and soft budget constraints on enterprises. Trade was heavily dependent on exchanges with other FSU republics, especially Russia, which in 1991 accounted for 91 % of exports and 88% of imports. 1.2 MIedium and long-term prospects for economic growth are good, largely due to the country's extensive natural resource base. However, since independence the economic situation in the country has deteriorated sharply. GDP declined by 15% per annum in 1992 and by 25% in 1994. During 1994, the decline was exacerbated by a severe winter, and continuing difficulties over oil trade with Russia. Output suffered from a steep fall in investment expenditures, depressed consumption levels, and cutbacks in defense outlays. The monthly inflation accelerated throughout 1993 and early 1994, to peak at 35 percent monthly during the second quarter of 1994. It has declined sharply since, to 5 percent a month by March 1995. This has been in response to the tightening of monetary policy, which followed the inter-enterprise arrears refinancing of April 1994. In addition, the level of inter-enterprise arrears rose rapidly, reaching an amount comparable to total outstanding bank credit to enterprises by March 1994. While registered unemployment has remained low (para 1.5), real average wages fell by 30% in 1992, 7% in 1993, and an estimated 23% in 1994. 1.3 The Government's reform program progressed well initially, before stalling somewhat in 1993 and the first half of 1994. A new Government tearn appointed in October 1994 and confirmed in March 1995 has shown greater conmmitment to deepening critical reforms. Enterprise restructuring and privatization have been important elements of the program, with the adoption of a three-pronged approach to privatization, embodied in a "National Privatization program for 1993-95." Under the small scale privatization program (under 200 employees), about 2,900 establishments had been privatized by the end of 1994, and a further 4,000 have been earnarked for sale by the end of 1995. In the mass privatization program (for firms with 200 to 5,000 employees), 275 enterprises had been offered for sale by September 1994, of a total of around 2,500 earmarked by the Government. Under the case-by-case privatization of large scale enterprises, the State Comrnittee on Privatization is planning to issue by June 1995, consultant tenders for the sale of at least 10 large enterprises through case by case tenders and another 15 during the rest of the year. It is expected that the committee will have finalized, by the end of 1995, at least 10 major transactions. Overall, privatization in the agricultural sector was proceeding ahead of schedule as of the fourth quarter of 1994, with 850 state farms privatized or undergoing privatization by the end of 1994, bringing to 1,455 the total number of state farms that are undergoing or have completed the privatization process (two thirds of the total number of state farms). Ihe Labor Market 1.4 Under the Soviet system, employment was guaranteed, and cash wages were low and relatively compressed. Wages were not related to productivity, resulting in low returns to labor. Enterprises functioned both as productive units and instruments of state social protection policy. This
 Page 2 Chapter I encouraged overstaffing, which is estimated to have been in the range of 20-30 %. In addition, non-cash income constituted a substantial proportion of labor remuneration: housing, kindergartens, health facilities, food stores, and other facilities. In 1992, non-cash income was estimated at over 40% of total labor compensation. This, and other factors such as the propiska residence permit system, resulted in low geographical mobility of labor. 1.5 As budget constraints on enterprises have increased, the employer response has been to place workers on unpaid leave or part-time work, resulting in increasing under-employment. As a result of this practice, open unemployment has remained low. The reluctance to formally retrench workers has been motivated by a number of factors, including social protection considerations, severance pay provisions (para 1.9), and employer expectations of resumed output growth in the medium-term. However, as state credits dry up and increasing numbers of enterprises are privatized, enterprises are likely to be forced to lay off workers permanently, converting current under-employment to open unemployment. 1.6 Large output falls since 1990 will combine with other factors to increase open unemployment, which is estimated to reach 4% by the end of 1995, and around 10% by the end of 19962. The duration of unemployment is also expected to increase significantly in the medium-tern, as lay-off rates outstrip absorption in the emerging private sector. These developments will increase the potential for social dislocation and place new and increasing burdens on the Employment Service (ES). Employment Service (ES) 1.7 The Ministry of Labor (MOL) is responsible for the operation of the ES through the Department of Employment (DOE). The ES has offices at the national, oblast (21 offices) and raion (300 offices) levels, with a total full-time staff of approximately 2,650 (or around 3,650, if ancillary and part-time staff are included). The Republic office sets national policy and distributes guidelines to oblasts on implementation, in addition to monitoring oblast ES performance. Raion offices are responsible for delivery of services, with oblast offices providing management support. Oblast offices have an average of 30 staff, and raion offices between 4 and 18 staff. Staff are allocated on a per capita of population basis (15:100,000), a norm used in other FSU republics. There have been no attempts to date to relate staffing levels to the regional unemployment profile. To ensure that staffing levels reflect actual workloads and the labor market needs of particular locations, a simple staffing formula needs to be developed (para 3.9) to provide a more flexible method of setting and reviewing staffing levels for each office. The challenge facing the ES is to reorient its functions from largely data collection on enterprise vacancies to a range of client-oriented services, including registration and payment of unemployment benefit (UB), client counseling job information, training and retraining, and temporary employment schemes (paras 3.12-3.29). 1.8 The ES was established in 1991, and is funded by a 2% payroll tax3. Initially, the Employment Fund (EF) was an extrabudgetary fund, but was absorbed into the budget in 1994. As a result of agreements under the SAL in April 1995, the EF became independent of the budget. Unemployment Benefits (UB) 1.9 Unemployment benefits were introduced in 1991, and are financed from the EF. When a worker is laid off, the employer must pay two months severance pay. After this period, the individual applies for registration as unemployed. If the application is approved, individuals are entitled to six months of UB. To date, expenditures on unemployment benefit have been low for a number of reasons, including the low number of registered unemployed, overly strict procedures for approval of UB payment, there appears to be an element of embarrassment associated with registering as unemployed and more particularly with receiving UB. At the end of 1994, 100,000 people were registered as unemployed or about 1.4% of the labor force. However, estimates of actual unemployment ranged between 450,000 and 550,000 (about 6.1% to 7.5% of the labor force). Up to recently, the level of benefit had been related to previous earnings and the minimrnum wage (para 3.14). 1.10 The primary function of the ES should be registration of the unemployed, payment of UB, and counseling and referral of clients to employment opportunities or training. An important aspect of its reorientation will be to improve the currently low public perception of the role which it can play. This will require a range of reforms, including revised staff allocation mechanisms, an improved registration system, training of staff, and refitting of offices. In addition, it will be necessary to encourage measures such as factory-gate hiring, which could lessen the burden on the ES. In its Letter of Development Policy for the SAL, the Government recognizes the social effects of the major increase in open unemployment, which has already begun and which is forecast to accelerate in the months ahead. It further recognizes, that labor mobility needs to be increased and that workers should move from inefficient activities to new areas of productivity and economic growth. The Government recognizes that at present, the system of UB has several weaknesses, i.e. the level of benefits is too low to provide any significant relief for the unemployed or inducement for employees to accept retrenchment. It further recognizes that the UB administration system is unduly complicated and the eligibility for unemployment benefits is overly restrictive. The structure of unemployment benefits also needs to be reconsidered in ways which will protect those most in need while avoiding work disincentives for other groups. To address this situation, the Government will carry out a series of reforms, which are to be implemented under this project (paras 3.14-3.16, 3.28 and Annex 1) Training and Retraining 1.11 Training and retraining in Kazakhstan are the responsibility of the Republican Center for Vocational Training within the DOE, which is separate from the ES. A portion of retraining is still carried out under the multi-party contractual arrangement which guarantees trainees a job, although such guarantees are becoming increasingly unenforceable. According to the DOE, during the last quarter of 1994, 70% of those undertaking training found jobs at the end of the course. Temporary Employment Schemes (TES) 1.12 In Kazakhstan, any person registered as a jobseeker with the ES can participate in temporary employment schemes. TES involve a broad range of activities, mostly of a low-skilled nature. During 1993, 11,300 people participated in TES; 47.7% were registered unemployed; 51 % were young persons below 20 years and 6.2% single mothers and mothers with many children. The number had fallen to only 4,400 by November 1994. An unemployed person can claim UB or work on TES for a maximum of 6 months out of every 12. The overall schedule of payment to participants involves a complex calculation of the average wage in the industry where the worker is placed. The wage paid to participants in TES cannot be less than the minimum UB plus 15 %. Social Protection and Social Services 1.13 The system of social protection during the Soviet period offered a wide array of cash and in-kind benefits, with little targeting of assistance on the basis of need. There was also limited emphasis on linking individual contributions to the level of benefits. These factors resulted in relatively high benefit expenditures, e.g. public pension expenditures accounted for around 9.5% of GDP in 1993. Tightening fiscal constraints since independence have resulted in various reforms, aimed at reining in social protection expenditures. There have been attempts to target and reduce expenditures on social protection, e.g. through the removal of food subsidies during 1993 and 1994, and the introduction of means-testing for family allowances. Real benefit levels have fallen sharply as a result -- pension and social assistance benefits are estimated to have declined 27% in real terms in 1994, after falling 26% in 1993. 1.14 The entire cash benefit structure has been linked to the minimum wage traditionally. However, by March 1994, the minimum wage had fallen to only 12% of the officially calculated poverty line, undermining the social protection function of benefits. This has led to use, on an informal basis of a simplified food basket for setting some benefits (such as family allowances) and consideration of reforms in setting of other benefits (such as UB). 1.15 In addition to the benefit system, Kazakhstan - similar to other republics of the FSU - maintained social services with high coverage rates and free and universal access. Of total social service expenditures, about a third appear to have been made by enterprises. However, since independence, both budget and enterprise-financed social services have been subject to sharp cuts in real allocations, though the fall is more difficult to estimate in the case of enterprise-financed services, due to lack of transparency in credit allocation mechanisms. The welfare impact of the cut is worsened by changes in the relative costs of inputs, which have resulted in an increasing share of budgets being spent on staff salaries and energy costs, e.g. 80% of the 1994 health budget was allocated to salaries and utilities. The crisis in health and education provision has been accelerated by privatization and the beginnings, in 1994, of harder budget constraints on enterprises. These have resulted in a range of responses: lower standards of service provision, divestiture of social assets to local authorities, closures of facilities, and in some cases, continued operation of services by enterprises at the expense of their productive competitiveness.
 Chapter I Page 5 1.16 An existing financing issue which the current fiscal crisis has brought into sharper relief is the method of budgetary allocation for social services provided by local authorities. Funds are allocated by higher levels of government on the basis of centrally determined norms (e.g. cost per bed; cost per student; capital costs per square meter). The budgetary process is increasingly inappropriate in a context of rapid devolution of responsibility for social services to the local level. In addition, the allocations appear to be inadequate to operate and maintain essential social services. Thus, assumption of additional responsibilities for social service provision by local authorities has widened local budget deficits, resulting in closure of some education and health facilities, and falling service standards at the others. Both municipal and enterprise facilities are operating at minimal levels due to severe lack of critical equipment and consumables, and deferred maintenance. In the short-term, however, the sustainability of social services depends more on increasing the availability of operating resources than in providing investment capital. 1.17 The position of local authorities is further constrained by the fiscal regime in Kazakhstan, which does not give oblasts or raions authority to levy new taxes, or vary the rate of existing taxes. In addition, their discretion to set user charges is constrained, e.g. the Presidential Decree capping user charges in kindergartens at 30% of food costs. Local authorities thus have extremely limited room for manoeuver on both the revenue and expenditure fronts. In some areas, enterprises are alleviating local financing difficulties through voluntary sponsorship of social services. In addition, some areas have already begun to explore more cost effective methods of service provision e.g. the introduction in Shymkent City of the "family doctor" program, which performs many of the functions of polyclinics. Divestiture of Social Assets 1.18 A significant legacy of the Soviet period was the widespread ownership, provision, and financing of social services by enterprises. Overall, non-productive social assets accounted for 31 % of all capital assets in Kazakhstan at the end of 1991. Of this total, 63% was housing stock owned by enterprises, 11% municipal services, 10% health care facilities, and 5% educational facilities. Other enterprise social assets included sanatoria, children's summer camps, sport and cultural facilities, and subsidized canteens. In many areas, enterprises provided social services not only to current and past employees and their families, but also to other members of the surrounding community. The range and quality of enterprise social service provision varied according to the size and strategic importance of the enterprise. 1.19 There were significant regional variations in the relative importance of enterprises in the provision of essential social services. In many areas (such as the numerous mono-company towns in the country) enterprises provided the bulk of certain types of social services e.g. in Ekibastuz, there were 50 enterprise and only 5 municipal kindergartens in the last quarter of 1994. In other areas (such as Shymkent City), enterprises and municipalities provided roughly equivalent numbers of such facilities. In other areas (including Almaty City and most rural areas), the majority of social services were provided by local authorities. The selected cities under the project include areas where enterprises have provided the bulk of essential social services (such as Kentau), and others where provision has been divided more evenly between local authorities and enterprises (such as Pavlodar and Shymkent). 1.20 Much of the investment in social assets by enterprises was made through the Social Fund within each enterprise, which absorbed 11 % of all enterprise profits in 1992. The result of such expenditure levels in Kazakhstan has been that enterprise-owned social assets are frequently of significantly higher quality than budget-financed facilities, both in terms of the structures themselves, and
 Page 6 Chapter I the unit costs of service provision (e.g. costs per child in enterprise kindergartens in selected localities in Pavlodar oblast were more than three times the level of budget facilities). 1.21 The most immediate effect of the transition on enterprise expenditures has been a dramatic fall in investment in social asset construction. Between 1991 and 1992, construction by enterprises of kindergartens fell by 63 %, of health facilities by 43 %, and of schools by 50%. Project preparation work indicates that - at least in South Kazakhstan and Pavlodar oblasts - construction of social assets had ceased altogether by 1994, and that budgets for capital repairs and maintenance are under increasing pressure. 1.22 Although local authorities are assuming ownership and responsibility for divested social assets, they have not been given increased budgetary allocations commensurate with the additional social service burden. Local responses to this situation have varied according to the proportional increase in responsibilities, and the pre-existing fiscal situation and administrative capacity in the locality. In areas where local authorities have traditionally provided the bulk of social services, there is some capacity to cope with the increased burden, where necessary by absorbing users of enterprise facilities into the existing budget-financed system, and closing divested facilities. However, even some of these areas are experiencing severe difficulties in meeting the costs of the existing social service system, as evidenced by wage payment arrears for teachers in budget-financed educational facilities in several project cities. In Kentau, municipal kindergartens were closed in the second half of 1994 due to absence of funds (para 3.32). B. Government's Reform Strategy 1.23 The Government's reform strategy aims at achieving macro-economic stabilization and implementing structural and sectoral reforms. The key elements of this strategy that have assumed priority for the next few years are: (i) developing competitive markets throughout the economy, particularly in agriculture; (ii) reforming the enterprise and financial sectors; (iii) putting in place adequate social protection policies; and (iv) addressing bottlenecks in infrastructure and energy, and cleaning up the environment. 1.24 The Government is committed to policies which will facilitate the emergence of viable private enterprises. Consistent with this premise, its main strategy vis-a-vis the enterprise sector is to transform it from a state-owned administered one, into one dominated by privately owned capitalist firms, which will operate under competitive market conditions. This will be achieved through both the entry of new firms and the privatization of existing ones. 1.25 The Government recognizes that without a viable social safety net for people living below the poverty line and a strategy to ensure the delivery of primary services, the sustainability of the entire reform program will be threatened. Employment Services 2.1 International experience suggests that Employment Services should combine programs of passive measures (e.g. registration of the unemployed and payment of unemployment benefits) with proactive measures (such as training and Temporary Employment Schemes (TES)). Proactive measures generally cost more than cash benefits, but may decrease the duration of unemployment and increase productivity. However, financing plans should ensure that proactive measures do not subsume budgetary allocations for passive measures such as the payment of UB. 2.2 Bank experience in implementing Employment Service projects in other countries suggests that the quality of staff is critical. Upgrading staff skills is a prerequisite for effective service delivery and use of updated office technology. Automation is also essential to an efficient employment service, provided that computer applications are based on well-designed programs and operational procedures. Nevertheless, the difficulty of developing and implementing a comprehensive employment service automation plan should not be underestimated, particularly in an environment characterized by rapidly rising unemployment and limited local capacity. 2.3 Experience from Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) countries and elsewhere in the FSU suggests that women are more affected by unemployment than men during the early stages of restructuring. They are laid off more often, and their reemployment prospects are lower.4 As restructuring progresses, lay-off rates converge for men and women, but re-employment prospects remain lower for women. Youth unemployment in CEE countries has also been high, up to 3-4 times the general unemployment rate. A further lesson of CEE experience is that policies for dealing with the long-term unemployed should be an important part of the ES mandate. Finally, our experience with the implementation of the Russia Employment Service and Social Protection Project suggest that ownership of the project from an early stage of design/preparation is key to the successful implementation of a project. Benefits 6.1 The policy making capacity of the Employment Service will be improved, and the basis laid for a program of social protection to retrenched workers. The provision of an effective social safety net will remove constraints on labor mobility and improve public support for the Government's economic strategy. Enterprise restructuring will be facilitated in the selected cities by the orderly divestiture of social assets. The project will foster rationalization of local social service budget management and improve public social investment programs in the selected cities. Improvements in the cost effectiveness of local social expenditures will have a net positive impact on the central budget, reducing the need for increased budgetary allocations resulting from divestiture, while allowing local governments to operate additional divested social services. Experience with the rationalization programs in the two oblasts will facilitate replication/improvement of the approach subsequently throughout the country. B. Risks 6.2 In a newly created country undergoing fundamental economic transformation, there is an inevitable risk of policy changes and implementation delays. The project faces five main risks: (i) the Government's limited experience with Bank-financed projects and overall limited administrative capacity; . (ii) the complexity of the issues to be addressed; (iii) introduction of user fees for health services may be delayed because changes in the legislation need to be introduced; (iv) the Government may find it difficult to sustain the level of management, coordination, and budgetary effort required to succeed in the divestiture process; and (v) delays in implementing policy reforms may jeopardize project implementation. The project would help offset these risks by: putting in place strong institutional arrangements; implementing the Social Services Component in oblasts/cities where the local administrations are committed to implementing structural changes in the social sector, through rationalization of social service expenditures, generating substantial cost savings in the running of social assets; providing management support and training for the implementation of the rationalization plans, including building a national capacity through the training of financial staff both at the central and oblast/city level; and providing technical assistance to the ES to implement improved organizational procedures prior to project start-up. In addition, the project's technical assistance inputs and the reporting relationships and responsibilities of the PCU are being designed so as to minimize the risks, which would also be given particular attention by supervision missions. C. Environmental Impact 6.3 The proposed project comprises technical assistance, training, introduction of management infornation systems, modest rehabilitation of health care facilities and kindergartens; and provision of essential medical equipment and drugs. As such, no adverse impact on the environment is expected from the proposed project (Screening Category C).

doc.abstracts: The Social Protection Project seeks to: 1) develop the capacity of the Employment Service in the Department of Employment (DOE) of the Ministry of Labor (MOL) to manage the expected increase in the number of registered unemployed and attendant benefit claims following the restructuring and privatization of enterprises; and 2) ensure continued delivery of essential social services, by promoting orderly divestiture of social assets from enterprises, and efficient management by municipalities of a unified system of social services. To meet these objectives, the project has two main components: 1) an Employment Service (ES) Component to be implemented at both national and regional levels; and a Social Services Component, to be implemented in selected cities of South Kazakstan and Pavlodar oblasts. The Employment Service (ES) Component will strengthen the institutional capacity of the ES to register the unemployed and calculate and pay unemployment benefits; provide a more effective service to unemployed jobseekers; and analyze labor markets and formulate labor market policies. The Social Services Component will facilitate the transfer of essential social services from restructuring enterprises to local governments, and rationalize management of all basic services in five selected cities : Shymkent City, Kentau, Lenger, Pavlodar City, and Aksu.
